claims.claim: The global yarn market is expected to grow by USD 39.9 billion from 2025-2029, at a CAGR of 5.3%
claims.verification_note: Single source (Technavio). Note: This covers ALL yarn, not just craft/hobby yarn. Different research firms report varying figures.

claims.claim: The global knitting yarn market was valued at USD 7,177.3 million in 2024 and is expected to reach USD 9,965.3 million by 2031 (CAGR 4.8%)
claims.verification_note: DISCREPANCY: Knitting yarn market estimates range from $4.7B to $18.5B across different research firms - nearly 4x difference. Use with caution.

claims.claim: The global Knitting and Crochet Market is expected to grow USD 12,279.9 million from 2025-2029, at a CAGR of 6.9%
claims.verification_note: Single source (Technavio). Consistent with general growth trajectory but specific figures should be treated as estimates.

claims.claim: Swiss online retailer Galaxus reported that sales of knitting needles, sewing machines, fabric scissors and wool rose by 646% from April 2020 to March 2021
claims.verification_note: Specific company claim, well-documented. Note: Not all retailers saw similar gains - results varied by location and product mix.

claims.claim: Knitting pattern sales increased by 25% during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020
claims.verification_note: General trend confirmed across multiple sources; specific percentage not independently verified.

claims.claim: Lion Brand (143-year-old yarn company) sales were up 80% since coronavirus lockdowns began
claims.verification_note: Specific company statement, widely reported in media.

claims.claim: In 2020, The Guardian reported a 140% increase in the number of people taking up crochet
claims.verification_note: Attributed to The Guardian reporting; consistent with other pandemic crafting boom reports.

claims.claim: We Are Knitters sales increased 75% each week during the pandemic crisis, with social media following growing by 50%
claims.verification_note: Company founder statement, consistent with industry trends.

claims.claim: Etsy more than doubled its revenues in 2020, with sales up 39% for first nine months of 2021
claims.verification_note: Public company financial data, verifiable.

claims.claim: The average age of yarn consumers is 58 (median 59); 98% are female with household income between $72,000-$91,500
claims.verification_note: 2024 Craft Industry Alliance survey (n=7,000+). Note: Survey population may skew older/more engaged; may not represent all crafters.

claims.claim: 48% of yarn consumers are retired; 31% employed full-time; 73% crochet, 84% knit, 58% do both
claims.verification_note: 2024 Craft Industry Alliance survey. Consistent methodology, large sample size.

claims.claim: There are over 7.3 million knitters in the UK and 53 million knitters in the USA
claims.verification_note: Original source unclear. 2016 AFCI study cited 28.8M Americans knitting/crocheting. 53M figure may be outdated or conflated with crochet.

claims.claim: The hashtag #knittok has over 1.1 billion views on TikTok
claims.verification_note: Consistently cited across sources. TikTok metrics change frequently; represents point-in-time snapshot.

claims.claim: The hashtag #crochet has 13.9-37.3 billion views on TikTok
claims.verification_note: WIDE VARIATION: Sources report 2B (2021) to 37.3B (2024). True figure depends on date; rapid growth confirmed.

claims.claim: PetiteKnit (Mette Wendelboe Okkels) has over 1 million Instagram followers
claims.verification_note: Verifiable on Instagram; consistent across sources.

claims.claim: Crochet influencer Monet Nejon has 3.3 million TikTok followers
claims.verification_note: Verifiable on TikTok; may have changed since publication.

claims.claim: European shoulder construction remains a top trend, popularized by Scandinavian designs like PetiteKnit's Lyon Sweater
claims.verification_note: Multiple knitting industry sources confirm; widely observed in pattern sales.

claims.claim: Texture techniques are trending: cables, popcorn stitches, brioche, Fishermen's Rib, bobbles
claims.verification_note: Multiple sources confirm; consistent with fashion industry trends.

claims.claim: Chunky and oversized knitting projects continue trending in 2025 as statement pieces
claims.verification_note: Multiple sources confirm; aligns with fashion trends.

claims.claim: Pantone Color of the Year 2025 is Mocha Mousse (earthy brown)
claims.verification_note: Official Pantone announcement; easily verified.

claims.claim: Blue paired with white is a standout color combination for colorwork in 2024-2025
claims.verification_note: Single source; subjective trend observation.

claims.claim: Marling technique (pairing two contrasting colors for heathered look) is trending
claims.verification_note: Single source; niche technique.

claims.claim: Dickies/collars/cowls are trending as the evolution from balaclavas popularity
claims.verification_note: Single source; accessory trend.

claims.claim: Eco-friendly yarns (organic cotton, bamboo, recycled) are increasingly popular due to ecological benefits
claims.verification_note: Multiple sources confirm; aligns with broader sustainability trends in fashion.

claims.claim: Upcycling trend: crafters repurposing old knits, using yarn from thrifted garments for patchwork pieces
claims.verification_note: Multiple sources confirm; consistent with slow fashion movement.

claims.claim: Quiet luxury trend: minimalist silhouettes, premium natural fibers, understated elegance
claims.verification_note: Aligns with broader fashion industry trend; widely documented.

claims.claim: 90% of surveyed knitters/crocheters reported feeling calmer; 80% reported increased happiness (University of Wollongong study, n=8,000)
claims.verification_note: CAVEAT: Peer-reviewed research notes limitations in craft-mental health studies; benefits may be overgeneralized. Self-reported data from crafters likely to skew positive.

claims.claim: 10% of mental health clinics have integrated knitting into therapeutic programs
claims.verification_note: Unverified; original source unclear. Therapeutic use is documented but specific percentage not confirmed.

claims.claim: 70% of new knitters cite relaxation and stress relief as their primary reason for starting
claims.verification_note: Consistent with other surveys; specific percentage not independently verified.

claims.claim: Ravelry's June 2020 redesign caused reports of seizures (~8 users), migraines, eye strain, and accessibility issues
claims.verification_note: Multiple news sources; widely documented controversy.

claims.claim: Ravelry has 9 million registered users and 1 million monthly active users
claims.verification_note: VERIFIED: Multiple sources confirm this figure from Ravelry's own March 2020 statement. Note: Data is from 2020; current figures may differ.

claims.claim: Ravelry accessibility issues remain unresolved as of late 2024
claims.verification_note: Confirmed by ongoing community complaints and lack of official resolution announcement.

claims.claim: BIPOC in Fiber directory (originally created by Jeanette Sloan in 2018) supports Black, Indigenous and POC fiber artists
claims.verification_note: Active website; verifiable resource.

claims.claim: Vogue Knitting established a Diversity Advisory Council (DAC) - first of its kind in the knitting community
claims.verification_note: Official Vogue Knitting initiative; verifiable.

claims.claim: #blackpeopledoknit hashtag created by designer Lorna Hamilton Brown to promote Black visibility in knitting
claims.verification_note: Documented in multiple sources; verifiable on social media.

claims.claim: Tom Daley went viral at 2020 Tokyo Olympics for crocheting poolside, creating his famous Tokyo 2020 Cardigan
claims.verification_note: Widely documented viral moment; Olympics 2021 (delayed from 2020).

claims.claim: Wool yarns most popular among consumers, followed by blended fibers, synthetic, cotton; only 2% prefer luxury yarns
claims.verification_note: 2024 Craft Industry Alliance survey data.

claims.claim: Modern granny squares featuring geometric patterns, hexagons, floral designs, and bold colors are trending
claims.verification_note: Multiple sources confirm resurgence of granny square patterns.

claims.claim: Gender-inclusive patterns with broader sizing and universal appeal are a growing trend
claims.verification_note: Observed industry trend; extent varies by designer/brand.

claims.claim: Multi-craft combinations blending knitting/crochet with applique, cross stitch, embroidery, beadwork are trending
claims.verification_note: Multiple sources confirm; part of broader maker movement.

claims.claim: Ravelry banned all pro-Trump patterns and content in June 2019, stating support for Trump administration is support for white supremacy
claims.verification_note: Well-documented in major news outlets (NPR, MIT Tech Review); direct quotes from Ravelry.

claims.claim: Ravelry's Trump ban led to creation of alternative platforms like Freedom Knits and Fiberkind (18,000 members)
claims.verification_note: Documented in MIT Tech Review; alternative platforms are verifiable.

claims.claim: Knitting.com purchased for $80,000 by e-commerce entrepreneurs who called existing businesses 'grandmas with little blogs', sparking massive backlash
claims.verification_note: Widely documented in Quartz, Daily Beast, Input; original podcast statements are on record.

claims.claim: r/craftsnark Reddit community (~14,000 members) serves as a hub for knitting community gossip and drama
claims.verification_note: Active subreddit; member count verifiable on Reddit.

claims.claim: Israel-Gaza tensions have caused community fragmentation, with r/JewishCrafts created as alternative space
claims.verification_note: Documented in The Forward; subreddit is verifiable.

claims.claim: In 2017, US yarn store count dropped below 1,000 (from 1,034 to 970) - losing 64 stores in one year
claims.verification_note: Single source (America's Knitting directory). Historical data; current situation may differ.

claims.claim: Local Yarn Store Day (LYS Day) established by TNNA, held annually (7th annual in 2024) to support brick-and-mortar shops
claims.verification_note: Official TNNA initiative; verifiable.

claims.claim: Over 73% of crocheters are between ages 18-34 according to Crochet Penguin
claims.verification_note: CONFLICTING DATA: Other sources cite 34% (Creative Industries Association), 44% (25-34 only). Wide discrepancy suggests different methodologies or populations.

claims.claim: 86% of Gen Z consider themselves hands-on creatives; 30% have taken an in-person arts and crafts class (Mintel 2024)
claims.verification_note: Mintel is reputable market research firm; methodology not reviewed.

claims.claim: TikTok helped make knitting 'cool and trendy again' after it was seen as 'uncool, outdated thing that only older ladies would do'
claims.verification_note: Multiple sources confirm TikTok's role in craft revival; qualitative observation widely shared.

claims.claim: Crochet aligned with cottagecore and grandmacore aesthetics, romanticizing pastoral lifestyle and vintage handmade garments
claims.verification_note: Multiple sources confirm aesthetic connection; documented cultural trend.

claims.claim: Knit/crochet age ranges are fairly even: 34% ages 18-34, 36% ages 35-54, 30% ages 55+
claims.verification_note: Source methodology not specified; provides different picture than 'average age 58' from industry survey.

claims.claim: 71% of US adults took part in at least one crafting project in 2024 (Mintel survey of 2,000 adults)
claims.verification_note: Mintel is reputable market research firm with documented methodology.

claims.claim: Community concerns include acrylic vs natural wool debates, knitfluencers overcharging, designer pricing, and parasocial relationships
claims.verification_note: Documented in Slate podcast and Reddit communities; ongoing discussions observable.

major_discrepancies: Market size estimates vary by up to 4x across research firms
Gen Z crafter percentages range from 34% to 73% depending on source
TikTok #crochet views reported from 2B to 37.3B (different dates)
Gender demographics vary: 71-98% female depending on survey population
well_verified_claims: Ravelry user statistics (9M registered, 1M MAU as of 2020)
Pandemic sales boom for specific companies (Lion Brand, Galaxus, Etsy)
Major community controversies (Trump ban, accessibility issues, Knitting.com)
cautions: Mental health benefit claims may be oversimplified; research has methodological limitations
Demographic data sources vary in methodology and population surveyed
Social media view counts are point-in-time and change rapidly
Some statistics are cited from blog aggregators rather than primary sources
